title: How do airplanes actually fly? - Raymond Adkins

multiple-choice.question: What was the main reason for the failure of Albert Einstein's airplane wing design in 1917?

options.label: A
options.text: The wing's curvature was too steep.

options.label: B
options.text: The wing's lift was not generated by the correct explanation.

options.label: C
options.text: The wing's material was too heavy.

options.label: D
options.text: The wing's shape was not aerodynamic.

multiple-choice.question: What is the "Longer Path" or "Equal Transit Time" explanation of lift?

options.label: A
options.text: The air molecules traveling above the wing reach the wing's trailing edge faster than the air beneath.

options.label: B
options.text: The air molecules traveling over the top of a curved wing cover a longer distance than those traveling underneath.

options.label: C
options.text: The air molecules traveling above the wing experience a decrease in speed.

options.label: D
options.text: The air molecules traveling below the wing experience an increase in speed.

multiple-choice.question: What is the actual explanation for the generation of lift?

options.label: A
options.text: The pressure difference between the upper and lower surfaces of the wing.

options.label: B
options.text: The air molecules traveling above the wing reach the wing's trailing edge faster than the air beneath.

options.label: C
options.text: The wing's curvature is the cause of lift.

options.label: D
options.text: The wing's shape is not aerodynamic.

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the air as it meets the wing's solid surface?

options.label: A
options.text: It splits into pathways above and below the wing.

options.label: B
options.text: It sticks to the wing and pulls the surrounding air with it.

options.label: C
options.text: It experiences a decrease in speed.

options.label: D
options.text: It experiences an increase in pressure.

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of the air above the wing experiencing centripetal acceleration?
What is the effect of the pressure difference between the upper and lower surfaces of the wing?

options.label: C
options.text: It has no effect on the wing.

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the airflow above the wing if it is too curved or steeply angled?

options.label: C
options.text: It has no effect on the wing.

title: You don't actually know what your future self wants - Shankar Vendantam

multiple-choice.question: What is the concept that the speaker refers to as the "illusion of continuity"?

options.label: A
options.text: The idea that people tend to imagine that they will remain the same in the future.

options.label: B
options.text: The concept that our future selves will be identical to our current selves.

options.label: C
options.text: The notion that our preferences and interests change over time.

options.label: D
options.text: The idea that our future selves will be more rational than our current selves.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the couple that the speaker uses as an example to illustrate the challenges of end-of-life care?
What is the philosophical concept that the speaker uses to illustrate the idea that our bodies and minds undergo significant changes over time?
What is the challenge that arises from the illusion of continuity when making promises to future selves?

options.label: A
options.text: The difficulty of keeping promises to future selves who may not share our current views.

options.label: B
options.text: The challenge of making promises to future selves who may not be able to fulfill them.

options.label: C
options.text: The difficulty of breaking promises to future selves who may not want us to keep them.

options.label: D
options.text: The challenge of making promises to future selves who may not exist.

multiple-choice.question: What is the first piece of advice that the speaker offers to address the challenges of the illusion of continuity?

options.label: A
options.text: To practice humility and acknowledge that our future selves may hold different views.

options.label: B
options.text: To be brave and take risks in pursuing new opportunities and challenges.

options.label: C
options.text: To stay curious and take an active role in shaping our future selves.

options.label: D
options.text: To focus on our current selves and ignore our future selves.

multiple-choice.question: What is the second piece of advice that the speaker offers to address the challenges of the illusion of continuity?

options.label: A
options.text: To be brave and take risks in pursuing new opportunities and challenges.

options.label: B
options.text: To practice humility and acknowledge that our future selves may hold different views.

options.label: C
options.text: To stay curious and take an active role in shaping our future selves.

options.label: D
options.text: To focus on our current selves and ignore our future selves.

multiple-choice.question: What is the third piece of advice that the speaker offers to address the challenges of the illusion of continuity?

options.label: A
options.text: To practice humility and acknowledge that our future selves may hold different views.

options.label: B
options.text: To be brave and take risks in pursuing new opportunities and challenges.

options.label: C
options.text: To stay curious and take an active role in shaping our future selves.

options.label: D
options.text: To focus on our current selves and ignore our future selves.

multiple-choice.question: What is the paradox that the speaker identifies regarding our future selves?

options.label: A
options.text: That our future selves will be identical to our current selves.

options.label: B
options.text: That our future selves will be weaker and frailer than our current selves.

options.label: C
options.text: That our future selves will be stronger and more capable than our current selves.

options.label: D
options.text: That our future selves will be the same as our current selves, but with different preferences.

multiple-choice.question: What is the challenge that arises from the illusion of continuity when passing laws and policies?

options.label: A
options.text: The difficulty of making laws and policies that are effective and fair.

options.label: B
options.text: The challenge of making laws and policies that are outdated or ineffective.

options.label: C
options.text: The difficulty of making laws and policies that are too complex.

options.label: D
options.text: The challenge of making laws and policies that are too simple.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's final message to his audience regarding the illusion of continuity?

options.label: A
options.text: To ignore our future selves and focus on our current selves.

options.label: B
options.text: To be brave and take risks in pursuing new opportunities and challenges.

options.label: C
options.text: To practice humility and acknowledge that our future selves may hold different views.

options.label: D
options.text: To stay curious and take an active role in shaping our future selves.

title: Is it possible to lose weight fast? - Hei Man Chan

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between Sam and Felix's approaches to weight loss?

options.label: A
options.text: Sam wants to lose weight fast, while Felix wants to lose weight slowly.

options.label: B
options.text: Sam wants to lose weight slowly, while Felix wants to lose weight fast.

options.label: C
options.text: Sam wants to gain weight, while Felix wants to lose weight.

options.label: D
options.text: Sam and Felix have the same approach to weight loss.

multiple-choice.question: What happens to Felix's body when he drastically cuts his calorie intake?

options.label: A
options.text: His body starts breaking down fat cells as a major energy source.

options.label: B
options.text: His body starts breaking down emergency glucose and muscle mass.

options.label: C
options.text: His body starts replenishing glycogen stores.

multiple-choice.question: What is the body's emergency glucose supply stored in?

options.label: C
options.text: Liver in the form of glycogen

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the body when emergency glucose is depleted?

options.label: A
options.text: The body starts replenishing glycogen stores.

options.label: B
options.text: The body starts breaking down fat cells as a major energy source.

options.label: C
options.text: The body starts breaking down muscle mass.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main problem with extreme calorie reduction diets?

options.label: B
options.text: They lead to nutritional problems and compromise the immune system.

options.label: C
options.text: They are not effective for weight loss.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of "detoxification diets"?

options.label: B
options.text: To restrict certain foods to provide specific nutrients in high quantities.

multiple-choice.question: What can happen to the immune system when following a juice diet for multiple weeks?

options.label: C
options.text: It becomes weaker due to a lack of essential fats and proteins.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between Sam's and Felix's approaches to exercise?

options.label: A
options.text: Sam does not exercise, while Felix exercises regularly.

options.label: B
options.text: Sam exercises regularly, while Felix does not exercise.

options.label: C
options.text: Sam exercises for weight gain, while Felix exercises for weight loss.

options.label: D
options.text: Sam and Felix have the same approach to exercise.

multiple-choice.question: What happens to Felix's muscle mass when he drastically cuts his calorie intake?

options.label: B
options.text: His muscle mass remains the same.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main emphasis of the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: The importance of trying to lose weight fast.

options.label: B
options.text: The dangers of extreme calorie reduction diets.

options.label: C
options.text: The importance of a sustainable dietary lifestyle.
